title: Count Subarrays With Fixed Bounds
question_content:
You are given an integer array nums and two integers minK and maxK.
A fixed-bound subarray of nums is a subarray that satisfies the following conditions:

	The minimum value in the subarray is equal to minK.
	The maximum value in the subarray is equal to maxK.

Return the number of fixed-bound subarrays.
A subarray is a contiguous part of an array.
 
Example 1:

Input: nums = [1,3,5,2,7,5], minK = 1, maxK = 5
Output: 2
Explanation: The fixed-bound subarrays are [1,3,5] and [1,3,5,2].

Example 2:

Input: nums = [1,1,1,1], minK = 1, maxK = 1
Output: 10
Explanation: Every subarray of nums is a fixed-bound subarray. There are 10 possible subarrays.

 
Constraints:

	2 <= nums.length <= 105
	1 <= nums[i], minK, maxK <= 106

solutions.content:
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
Divide the array into smaller subarrays at indices where nums[i] <minK or nums[i]>minK. Now process each subarray individually. For every subarray track all indices of minK and maxK. For every index in subarray find the last minK,maxK if both exists in subarray and add count for all the subarray having from start to last index(minK,maxK).

# Complexity
- Time complexity: O(n log n)
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity: O(n)
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
    long long getRes(vector<int>& nums,int si,int ei,int minK,int maxK){     
        vector<int> mink,maxk;  
        for(int i =si;i<=ei;i++){
            if(nums[i]== minK)mink.push_back(i);
            if(nums[i]== maxK)maxk.push_back(i); }
        
       long long res = 0;
       for(int i =si;i<=ei;i++){  
        auto a = lower_bound(mink.begin(),mink.end(),i);
        auto b = lower_bound(maxk.begin(),maxk.end(),i);
        
        if(a==mink.end()||b == maxk.end() )continue;
        int x = *(a) ;
        int y = *(b);
        int v = max(x,y);
        res+= (ei-v+1); }
        return res;  
    }
    
    long long countSubarrays(vector<int>& nums, int minK, int maxK) {
        int l = -1,r = -1;
        long long ans = 0;
        for(int i =0;i<nums.size();i++){
            if(nums[i]<=maxK && nums[i]>= minK){
                  if(l == -1)l = i; 
                     r = i;  }
            else{   
                if(l!=-1)
                ans+= getRes(nums,l,r,minK,maxK);
                l = -1,r = -1;
            if(nums[i]<=maxK && nums[i]>= minK){
                  if(l == -1)l = i; 
                      r = i;
            }   }   }
        
        if(l!= -1)
            ans += getRes(nums,l,r,minK,maxK);
        return ans;        
    }
```

# Intuition
Sweep along the array. Mark the last appereance of minK, maxK, and number outside the boundary as $a$,$b$,$x$. The start points of the subarray that ends here range from $x+1$ to $\text{min}(a,b)$. Example:

![image.png](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/435228d7-07a3-467c-bc1a-0ba372423488_1677912651.12321.png)


# Code
```
class Solution:
    def countSubarrays(self, nums: List[int], minK: int, maxK: int) -> int:
        x,a,b = -1,-2,-2
        res = 0
        for i,n in enumerate(nums):
            if n>maxK or n<minK: x = i
            if n == minK: a = i
            if n == maxK: b = i
            res += max(0, min(a,b) - x)
        return res

```

solutions.content:
This is inspired by  [this](https://leetcode.com/problems/count-subarrays-with-fixed-bounds/discuss/2708099/JavaC%2B%2BPython-Sliding-Window-with-Explanation) and [this](https://leetcode.com/problems/count-subarrays-with-fixed-bounds/discuss/2707997/Python-Two-Pointer-O(n)-time-and-O(1)-space) , those two are true experts :)

![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/752ce915-0799-4030-b5a4-5b36d494177f_1665949790.505257.png)

From the diagram above, we need to know the closetest bad point, min and max. We can have one pass to go through all the elements to figure those out then calculate the possible subarrays that meet the min and max bound condition.

```

class Solution:
    def countSubarrays(self, nums: List[int], minK: int, maxK: int) -> int:
                
        bad_point_temp = left_min_temp = left_max_temp = -1
        
        has_min = has_max = False
        
        sub_arr_cnt = 0
        
        for ix, num in enumerate(nums):
            
            if num > maxK or num < minK:
                bad_point_temp = ix
                has_min = False
                has_max = False

            if num == minK:
                left_min_temp = ix
                has_min = True
            
            if num == maxK:
                left_max_temp = ix
                has_max = True
            
            if has_min and has_max:
            
                sub_arr_cnt += min(left_min_temp, left_max_temp) - bad_point_temp
        
        return sub_arr_cnt
        

```

solutions.content:
### Approach 1: Brute Force (TLE)

Check all possible subarrays and keep track of current minimum ``mi`` and maximum ``ma``. If either ``mi < minK`` or ``ma > maxK``, then we stop checking subarrays starting with index ``i`` and move on to index ``i + 1``. Once we find a subarray with ``mi = minK`` and ``ma = maxK``, then increment the result by 1.
```
class Solution:
    def countSubarrays(self, nums: List[int], minK: int, maxK: int) -> int:
        result = 0
        n = len(nums)
        for i in range(n):
            mi = ma = nums[i]
            for j in range(i, n):
                mi = min(mi, nums[j])
                ma = max(ma, nums[j])
                if mi < minK or ma > maxK:
                    break
                if mi == minK and ma == maxK:
                    result += 1
        return result
```
**Complexity Analysis**
Note: ``N`` is the length of the input array ``nums``.
* Time Compleixty: ``O(N^2)`` since we use nested for loops to check all possible subarrays.
* Space Complexity: ``O(1)``. No extra space is used.

---

### Approach 2: Two Pointers
**Observation**

Suppose ``nums = [10,1,3,5,2,7,1,3,5,10,1,3], minK = 1, maxK = 5``.

![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/ccba3069-c610-49f2-aaa7-5f345bef414c_1665908301.2791028.png)

Obviously, numbers colored by gray are not between ``minK = 1`` and ``maxK = 5``. They won't be included in any fixed-bound subarrays. So, we only need to consider subarrays colored by yellow.

How to find subarrays colored by yellow? We can use **two pointers**: one is ``left`` and the other is ``right`` and **expand ``right`` one by one until we encounter a number that is not in the range ``[minK, maxK]``**.

OK, now, we know the way getting subarrays colored by yellow. But how to count how many fixed-bound subarrays exist in a subarray colored by yellow?

For a better explanation, let's take ``nums = [1, 3, 5, 1], minK = 1, maxK = 5`` for example.

First, let's see subarrays ending at index ``i = 3``.

![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/dd1b5386-e39c-4637-a73a-6e19b167b19d_1665917101.629008.png)

Do you find why the first 3 subarrays are fix-bound but the last one isn't? Because it doesn't include number ``5``.

To form a fix-bound subarray, it must include at least one ``minK`` and one ``maxK``. For the above ``nums``, the last ``minK = 1`` is at ``index = 3``, say ``lastMin``, and the last ``maxK = 5`` is at ``index = 2``, say ``lastMax``. So, to include both ``minK`` and ``maxK``, the largest starting index is exactly ``index = 2``, which is the minimum of ``lastMin`` and ``lastMax``. With ``index = 2``, we can easily **count the number of fix-bound subarrays ending at ``index = 3`` by calculating ``min(lastMin, lastMax) - st + 1``**.

**Algorithm**

1. Split ``nums`` into multiple subarrays by those numbers that are not between ``minK`` and ``maxK``.
2. Solve each subarrays ``nums[st...end]`` in step1 independently and sum all of them.
	(1) Keep track of the last occurrence of ``minK``, say ``lastMin``, and ``maxK``, say ``lastMax``, respectively.
	(2) Count number of fix-bound subarrays ending at each index by calculating ``min(lastMin, lastMax) - st + 1``
	
**Implementation**
<iframe src="https://leetcode.com/playground/A4Fpq84L/shared" frameBorder="0" width="800" height="600"></iframe>

**Complexity Analysis**
Note: ``N`` is the length of the input array ``nums``.
* Time Compleixty: ``O(N)``. In ``countSubarrays``, we compare each element in ``nums`` with ``minK`` and ``maxK`` once. In ``helper``, we also do the comparison for all elements in ``nums`` once. So the elements in ``nums`` are processed twice.
* Space Complexity: ``O(1)``. No extra space is used.

```
class Solution:
    def countSubarrays(self, nums: List[int], minK: int, maxK: int) -> int:
        i =  0 # left index
        j = 0  # right index
        ans = 0
        
        minn = [] # store the indices of minK in a window which have no element less than minK and greater than maxK 
        maxx = [] # store the indices of maxK in a window which have no element less than minK and greater than maxK
        
        while j<len(nums):
            if nums[j]==minK:
                minn.append(j)
            if nums[j]==maxK:
                maxx.append(j)

            if nums[j]<minK or nums[j]>maxK: # conflict
                a,b = 0,0 # indices of minn and maxx array
                while a<len(minn) and b<len(maxx):
                    m = max(minn[a],maxx[b])  # max index which should keep in subbarray necessarily
                    ans+=j-m                  # add how many subarray can create such that they start from nums[i]
                    if nums[i]==minK:
                        a+=1
                    if nums[i]==maxK:
                        b+=1
                    i+=1 
                # there is a conflict on indix j so clear minn and maxx array    
                minn.clear()
                maxx.clear()
                
                i = j+1 # set left pointer to j+1 (searching for new window which can start from j+1)
                
            j+=1        
                
        # after reaching j on last indix check if there is a window which is already created       
        a,b = 0,0
        while a<len(minn) and b<len(maxx):
            m = max(minn[a],maxx[b])
            ans+=j-m

            if nums[i]==minK:
                a+=1
            if nums[i]==maxK:
                b+=1
             
            i+=1        
                        
        return ans
```

solutions.title: python-sliding-window-o-n-time-o-1-space-explained
solutions.content:
```
def countSubarrays(self, nums: List[int], minK: int, maxK: int) -> int:
	ans = 0
	r = 0 # right of window
	l = 0 # left of window
	n = len(nums)
	recentMin = -1 # most recent instance of the max
	recentMax = -1 # most recent instance of the min
	while r < n:
		while r<n: # sliding to the right
			num = nums[r]
			if not minK<=num<=maxK: # if this number is too big or small we can no longer use this window
				break
			# now update the recent min and max if needed
			if num == minK:
				recentMin = r
			if num == maxK:
				recentMax = r
			r += 1
			if recentMin != -1 and recentMax != -1:
				ans += (min(recentMin,recentMax)-l)+1 # we can make as many new subarrays as the earliest occurrence of recentMin or recentMax minus the starting position of our window
		# reset everything
		r+=1
		l = r
		recentMin = -1
		recentMax = -1
	return ans
```

The toughest part of coming to this answer was figuring out what to add to ```ans```. I realized that we need to add ```(min(recentMin,recentMax)-l)+1``` by thinking of all the new subarrays we could create when we come across a new element. When we add a new element to our subarray (increase ```r``` by one), then we add as many new unique subarrays as we can create by moving ```l``` forward. We can only move ```l``` forward as longas ```recentMin``` and ```recentMax``` are within our sliding window ```[l,r]``` so we can create ```(min(recentMin,recentMax)-l)+1``` new subarrays!

detailed-explanation-of-python-o-n-solution
solutions.content:
# Intuition
We have to count all subarrays with certain properties. In such problems, a good pattern is to think about what happens when the subarrays end at a certain position. Let's iterate through the array and think about how to calculate the number of appropriate subarrays that end at a current position.

nums = [1,3,5,2,7,5], minK = 1, maxK = 5

How many subarrays end at index 0, val - 1? -> 0 (no element equals maxK)

How many subarrays end at index 1, 3? -> 0 (no element equals maxK)

How many subarrays end at index 2, 5? -> 1 (the leftmost border can't be further than the last minK)

How many subarrays end at index 3, 2? -> 1 (the leftmost border can't be further than the last minK)

How many subarrays end at index 4, 7? -> 0 (7 is bigger than maxK)

How many subarrays end at index 5, 5? -> 0 (no element equals minK after the first element that can't be in the subarray (bigger than maxK or smaller than minK))
the answer is the suma of this values = 2

If the right border is fixed (current index inx in iteration) and we know the leftmost possible index of the left border "llb" and the rightmost possible left border "rlb" then the total number of subarrays that end at the current index is rlb-llb+1. So we can calculate the subarrays that end at all indexes, and the total number of subarrays is just the sum of all of them.

The rest is just figuring out how to calculate the leftmost left possible subarray border (llb) and rightmost left possible subarray border (rlb).

For rlb, it is simple. We always need maxK and minK elements, so let's just take the minimum of their indexes before the current index = min(lastmaxKinx, lastminKinx).

The only restriction for the llb is that it should be after any inappropriate element. When we encounter an element that is greater than maxK or smaller than minK, we can set llb = current index + 1.

Consider the input array nums = [1,3,5,2,7,5] and the range constraints minK = 1, maxK = 5. Let's assume the right border is at index 3.

In this case, the leftmost left border(llb) is 1 at index 0 because there are no values between 1 and the right border that violate the constraints.

To calculate the rightmost left border(rlb), we need to find the index of the last minK or maxK element before the current index. In this case, the rightmost left border is also 1 because there is only one minK element and shifting the left border further right would exclude it.

Therefore, the leftmost left border (llb) and rightmost left border (rlb) are both 0. The total number of subarrays ending at index 3 can be calculated as rlb-llb+1=0-0+1=1, which is correct.


# Approach

To calculate the rlb,  maintain the indices of the last occurrences of the minK and maxK in variables, "last_minK" and "last_maxK".

Maintain left border (llb), the index of the next element AFTER the last element that violates the constraints in variable "left_most".

Iterate through the array and for each position, calculate the number of subarrays that end at that position: rlb-llb+1. 
Sum them up to the variable called "count".

# Complexity
- Time complexity: O(n) - we iterate once through the array and perform a constant amount of work for each element.
- Space complexity: O(1) - we only need a few variables to solve this problem.

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def countSubarrays(self, nums: List[int], minK: int, maxK: int) -> int:
        count = 0 # total amount
        last_minK = None # at initialization we dont have such elements
        last_maxK = None # at initialization we don't have such elements
        left_most = 0 # we have no elements before wich violates constraints, llb value

        for inx, n in enumerate(nums):
            if n < minK or n > maxK: # this elements violates constraints
                # last_minK and last_maxK cant be included in any window after inx
                left_most = inx+1
                last_minK = None
                last_maxK = None
            else:
                if n == minK:
                    last_minK = inx
                if n == maxK:
                    last_maxK = inx
                # we have both maxK and minK so lets calculate the number of subarrays ended at inx
                if last_minK is not None and last_maxK is not None:
                    right_most_left_border = min(last_minK, last_maxK)
                    count += right_most_left_border-left_most+1


        return count

```

solutions.title: python-short-and-clean-functional-programming
solutions.content:
# Approach
TLDR; Same as the [Official Solution](https://leetcode.com/problems/count-subarrays-with-fixed-bounds/editorial/).

# Complexity
- Time complexity: $$O(n)$$

- Space complexity: $$O(1)$$

where, `n is the length of nums`.

# Code
```python
class Solution:
    def countSubarrays(self, nums: list[int], minK: int, maxK: int) -> int:
        indexes = lambda f: accumulate(range(len(nums)), lambda a, x: x if f(nums[x]) else a, initial=-1)

        left_bounds = indexes(lambda num: num < minK or num > maxK)
        maxs = indexes(lambda num: num == maxK)
        mins = indexes(lambda num: num == minK)

        count_fn = lambda lb, mx, mn: max(0, min(mx, mn) - lb)
        return sum(map(count_fn, left_bounds, maxs, mins))


```

```
class Solution:

        ans=0
        minindex=-1
        maxindex=-1
        culprit=-1
        for i in range(len(nums)):
            if nums[i]<minK or nums[i]>maxK:
                culprit=i
            if nums[i]==minK:
                minindex=i
            if nums[i]==maxK:
                maxindex=i
            
            smaller=min(minindex,maxindex)
            temp=smaller-culprit
            if temp<=0:
                ans+=0
            else:
                ans+=temp
        return ans

        


        

```

<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
# Brute Force
The first approach that comes up is the Brute Force Approach where we check all possible subarrays and count the ones that have min & max value as given. 
# Optimization||Two Pointer||Sliding Window
We need to find the no of subarrays possible starting from each index i,in a single traversal.We achieve this by keeping track of the most recent occurrence of minK, maxK, and the first element outside the range [minK, maxK]. This way, we can compute the number of subarrays with the required properties using just a few simple arithmetic operations.
# Algorithm 
 1 :   Initialize variables n, count, nmink, nmaxk, rbound to the    size of the array, 0, n, n, and n, respectively. Also, initialize variable c to 0 to store the count of subarrays.

 2 :   Traverse the array from right to left using a for loop and do the following:

     a. If the current element is equal to minK, update the value of nmink to the current index.
     b. If the current element is equal to maxK, update the value of nmaxk to the current index.
     c. If the current element is greater than maxK or less than minK, update the value of rbound to the current index.
     d. If the difference between the indices of nmink and nmaxk is less than or equal to rbound, update the value of c by adding the difference between rbound and max(nmink, nmaxk).

 3 :   Return the value of c.

# Explanation with Example
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
Let's say we have an array nums = [1, 4, 3, 4, 4, 2, 4, 5], minK = 4, and maxK = 4. We can use the sliding window approach to count the subarrays where the minimum and maximum elements are equal to minK and maxK, respectively.

Starting from the right end, we have n = 8, rbound = 8, nmink = 8, nmaxk = 8, and c = 0.

For the last element, nums[7] = 5 is greater than maxK = 4, so we update rbound to 7.

For the second last element, nums[6] = 4 is equal to maxK, so we update nmaxk to 6. Also, since nmaxk is less than rbound, we calculate the number of subarrays that can be formed using the current window, which is rbound - max(nmink, nmaxk) = 2. So, we add 2 to the count c.

For the third last element, nums[5] = 2 is less than minK, so we update rbound to 5.

For the fourth last element, nums[4] = 4 is equal to maxK, so we update nmaxk to 4. Also, since nmaxk is less than rbound, we calculate the number of subarrays that can be formed using the current window, which is rbound - max(nmink, nmaxk) = 1. So, we add 1 to the count c.

For the fifth last element, nums[3] = 4 is equal to maxK, so we update nmaxk to 3. Also, since nmaxk is less than rbound, we calculate the number of subarrays that can be formed using the current window, which is rbound - max(nmink, nmax)

# Complexity Comparison
- Time complexity: O(n)
  The optimized approach uses a single pass through the array, where we keep track of the indices of the most recent occurrence of minK, maxK, and the first element outside the range of [minK, maxK]. Since we only need to process each element of the array once, the time complexity of the optimized approach is O(n), where n is the size of the array.

  On the other hand, the Brute Force approach uses two nested for loops to iterate over all possible pairs of indices, and for each pair, we iterate over the subarray between them to check the minimum and maximum elements. This leads to a time complexity of O(n^3), where n is the size of the array.

  Therefore, the optimized approach is much faster than the Brute Force approach when it comes to time complexity.
- Space complexity: O(1)
   The optimized approach uses a constant amount of extra space to store some variables and the counter, which leads to a space complexity of O(1).

   The Brute Force approach does not use any extra space to store the subarrays or their minimum and maximum elements, but it does use a counter variable to keep track of the count of subarrays. Therefore, the space complexity of the Brute Force approach is also O(1).

  Therefore, both approaches have the same space complexity of O(1).


# Code
```
class Solution {
public:
    long long countSubarrays(vector<int>& nums, int minK, int maxK) {
        int n=nums.size();
        int rbound=n;
        int nmink=n;
        int nmaxk=n;
        long long int c=0;
        for(int i=n-1;i>=0;i--){
            if(nums[i]==minK) nmink=i;
            if(nums[i]==maxK) nmaxk=i;
            if(nums[i]>maxK||nums[i]<minK) rbound=i;
            if(rbound-max(nmink,nmaxk)>0) c+=rbound-max(nmink,nmaxk);
            // cout<<c<<rbound<<max(nmink,nmaxk)<<endl;(FOR DEBUGGING)
        }
        return c;
    }
};
```

```
def countSubarrays(self, nums: List[int], minK: int, maxK: int) -> int:
        count = last = 0
        min_index = max_index = -1
        for i, num in enumerate(nums):
            if num < minK or num > maxK:
                last = i + 1
                min_index = max_index = -1
                continue
            if num == minK:
                min_index = i
            if num == maxK:
                max_index = i
            if min_index != -1 and max_index != -1:
                count += min(max_index, min_index) - last + 1
        return count
```

The given code is an implementation of a function called 'countSubarrays' that takes in a list of integers 'nums', and two integer values 'minK' and 'maxK' and returns the count of all contiguous subarrays in 'nums' that have elements between 'minK' and 'maxK', inclusive. Here's a step-by-step explanation of the code:
1. Define a function named 'countSubarrays' that takes three input arguments: 'nums' (a list of integers), 'minK' (an integer), and 'maxK' (an integer), and returns an integer.
1. Initialize 'count' and 'last' variables to 0. Initialize 'min_index' and 'max_index' variables to -1.
1. Loop through each index 'i' and element 'num' in the 'nums' list:
	1. If the 'num' is less than 'minK' or greater than 'maxK', set 'last' to 'i+1', 'min_index' and 'max_index' to -1 and continue to the next iteration.
	1. If the 'num' is equal to 'minK', set 'min_index' to the current index 'i'.
	1. If the 'num' is equal to 'maxK', set 'max_index' to the current index 'i'.
	1. If both 'min_index' and 'max_index' are not equal to -1, calculate the count of contiguous subarrays between the two indices, update the 'count' variable and set 'last' to the next index after the calculated subarray.
1. Return the 'count' variable.

Note that the time complexity of this algorithm is O(n), where n is the length of the 'nums' list. This is because we are traversing the list only once and performing a constant number of operations for each element.

```
class Solution:
    def countSubarrays(self, nums, minK, maxK):
        minfound = maxfound = False
        start = minstart = maxstart = 0
        total = 0

        for i in range(len(nums)):
            if nums[i] == minK:
                minstart = i
                minfound = True
            if nums[i] == maxK:
                maxstart = i
                maxfound = True
            if not minK <= nums[i] <= maxK:
                minfound = maxfound = False
                start = i+1
            if minfound and maxfound:
                total += min(minstart,maxstart) - start + 1

        return total
```

**Main Idea**:
+ Sliding window with first = [0, n-1], and expanding last = [first, n-1] where nums[last]>=minK and nums[last]<=maxK
+ Maintaining position of min, max of the sliding window
+ Updating ans <- ans + (last - max(pos min, posmax) + 1) at every sliding window

**Examples**:

```
min/maxK, nums:  1 5 [1, 3, 5, 2, 7, 5]

pmin/max, last, d, ans:  [] [2] 3 0 2
pmin/max, last, d, ans:  [] [2] 3 0 2
pmin/max, last, d, ans:  [] [] 3 0 2
pmin/max, last, d, ans:  [] [5] 5 0 2
ans:  2
```

```
from sortedcontainers import SortedList

class Solution:
    def countSubarrays(self, nums: List[int], minK: int, maxK: int) -> int:
        print("min/maxK, nums: ", minK, maxK, nums)
        n = len(nums)
        pmin, pmax = SortedList([]), SortedList([])
        ans = 0
        last = -1
        for i in range(n):
            if nums[i]>=minK and nums[i]<=maxK:
                if last<i:
                    last = i
                    pmin.clear()
                    pmax.clear()
                    if nums[i]==minK:
                        pmin.add(i)
                    if nums[i]==maxK:
                        pmax.add(i)
                while last+1<n and nums[last+1]>=minK and nums[last+1]<=maxK:
                    if nums[last+1]==minK:
                        pmin.add(last+1)
                    if nums[last+1]==maxK:
                        pmax.add(last+1)
                    last = last + 1
                
                d = 0
                if len(pmin)>0 and len(pmax)>0:
                    d = last - max(pmin[0], pmax[0]) + 1
                ans = ans + d
                print("pmin/max, last, d, ans: ", list(pmin), list(pmax), last, d, ans)
                if nums[i]==minK:
                    pmin.discard(i)
                if nums[i]==maxK:
                    pmax.discard(i)
            else:
                last = -1
            pass
        print("ans: ", ans)
        print("=" * 20, "\n")
        
        return ans
```

# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
We add concept of breakpoints, that is elements greater than maxK or less than minK "breaks" the array into two parts, and if we start counting from left of a breakpoint, we cannot include any elements past it.

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
find breakpoints for all nums[i]. 
That is breakpoint[i] is the nearest breakpoint to the right of nums[i]
nums= 1 3 5 2 7 5
breakpoints= 4 4 4 4 4 6
Brute Force as usual, but once the inner loop(j),has satisfied the condition , the number of elements you can include from j are j-breakpoints[j]. add this to total count and go to next i.

# Example
        1 3 5 2 7 5
        break on elements > maxK or <minK
        1 3 5 2 |7| 5
        you cannot take left from index 5 or right from index 3.
        loop i from 0 to len(nums) 
            j from i to len(nums)
        now 1 3 5 2 |7| 5
                ^
                |
        when j is at 5 we have satisfied condition.
        number of elements before breakpoint is the number of arrays
        we can form from here.
        so we find that and go to next i , without increasing j.

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
O(n^2)

- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
O(n)
# Code
```
class Solution(object):
    def countSubarrays(self, nums, minK, maxK):
        c=0
        breakpts=[len(nums)]*len(nums)
        breakpt=0
        #
        #to add breakpts, traverse:
        #if u find a breakpoint, make every elements before the most #recent breakpoint to have a breakpoint
            
        for i in range(0,len(nums)):
            if(nums[i]>maxK or nums[i]<minK):
                breakpts[breakpt:i+1]=[i]*(i+1-breakpt)
                breakpt=i
        print(breakpts)
        i=0
        while(i<len(nums)):
            mi=ma=nums[i]
            j=i
            while(j<len(nums)):
                mi,ma=min(mi,nums[j]),max(ma,nums[j])
                if(mi==minK and ma==maxK):
                    c+=(breakpts[j]-j)
                    break
                if(nums[j]>maxK or nums[j]<minK):
                    break
                j+=1
            i+=1
            if(j==len(nums)):
                return c
        return c
        '''
        1 3 5 2 7 5
        break on elements > maxK or <minK
        1 3 5 2 |7| 5
        you cannot take left from 5 or right from 2.
        loop i from 0 and j from i to traverse.
        now 1 3 5 2 |7| 5
                ^
                |
        from 5 , number of elements before breakpoint is the number of arrays we can form.
        so we find that and go to next i , without increasing j.
        '''
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
Calculating the count of subarrays qualified is harder than calculating the opposite. Then do the opposite and subtract it from number of all possible subarrays.

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
Whenever there's a value outside interval [minK, maxK], do a calculation as the previous part does not impact later anymore. 
Within each part, whenever there's a value == minK or maxK, we calculate the number of subarrays not qualified. 
If minK == maxK, this corner case is even easier and we can take another measure. 

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
O(n)
- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
O(1)
# Code
```
class Solution:
    def countSubarrays(self, nums: List[int], minK: int, maxK: int) -> int:
        
        nums.append(maxK + 1)
        n = len(nums)
        
        if minK == maxK: 
            cnt = 0
            res = 0
            for i in range(n): 
                num = nums[i]
                if num == minK: 
                    cnt += 1
                else:
                    res += cnt * (cnt + 1) // 2
                    cnt = 0
            return res                    
        
        startidx = None
        prevminidx = None
        prevmaxidx = None
        offset = 0
        res = 0
        
        for i in range(n): 
            num = nums[i]
            if num < minK or num > maxK: 
                if prevminidx is not None and prevmaxidx is not None: 
                    llast1 = (i - 1) - (max(prevminidx, prevmaxidx) + 1) + 1
                    llast2 = max(prevmaxidx, prevminidx) - (min(prevmaxidx, prevminidx) + 1) + 1
                    ltotal = (i - 1) - startidx + 1
                    offset += llast1 * (llast1 + 1) // 2 + llast1 * llast2
                    res += ltotal * (ltotal + 1) // 2 - offset
                startidx = None
                prevminidx = None
                prevmaxidx = None
                offset = 0  
                continue
            else: 
                if startidx is None: 
                    startidx = i
                if num == minK: 
                    if prevminidx is None and prevmaxidx is None: 
                        l = i - startidx + 1
                        offset += l * (l + 1) // 2
                    elif prevminidx is None: 
                        l1 = i - (prevmaxidx + 1) + 1
                        l2 = prevmaxidx - startidx + 1
                        offset += l1 * (l1 + 1) // 2 + (l1 - 1) * l2
                    elif prevmaxidx is None:
                        l1 = i - (prevminidx + 1) + 1
                        l2 = prevminidx - startidx + 1
                        offset += l1 * (l1 + 1) // 2 + l1 * l2
                    else: 
                        if prevmaxidx >= prevminidx: 
                            l1 = i - (prevmaxidx + 1) + 1
                            l2 = prevmaxidx - (prevminidx + 1) + 1
                            offset += l1 * (l1 + 1) // 2 + (l1 - 1) * l2
                        else: 
                            l1 = i - (prevminidx + 1) + 1
                            l2 = prevminidx - (prevmaxidx + 1) + 1
                            offset += l1 * (l1 + 1) // 2 + l1 * l2
                    prevminidx = i
                elif num == maxK: 
                    if prevminidx is None and prevmaxidx is None: 
                        l = i - startidx + 1
                        offset += l * (l + 1) // 2
                    elif prevmaxidx is None: 
                        l1 = i - (prevminidx + 1) + 1
                        l2 = prevminidx - startidx + 1
                        offset += l1 * (l1 + 1) // 2 + (l1 - 1) * l2
                    elif prevminidx is None: 
                        l1 = i - (prevmaxidx + 1) + 1
                        l2 = prevmaxidx - startidx + 1
                        offset += l1 * (l1 + 1) // 2 + l1 * l2
                    else: 
                        if prevminidx >= prevmaxidx: 
                            l1 = i - (prevminidx + 1) + 1
                            l2 = prevminidx - (prevmaxidx + 1) + 1
                            offset += l1 * (l1 + 1) // 2 + (l1 - 1) * l2
                        else: 
                            l1 = i - (prevmaxidx + 1) + 1
                            l2 = prevmaxidx - (prevminidx + 1) + 1
                            offset += l1 * (l1 + 1) // 2 + l1 * l2
                    prevmaxidx = i 
            
        return res            
        
```

```
            res = 0
            for i in range(n): 
                num = nums[i]
                if num == minK: 
                    cnt += 1
                else:
                    res += cnt * (cnt + 1) // 2
                    cnt = 0

        startidx = None
        prevminidx = None
        prevmaxidx = None
        offset = 0
```

# Intuition
Intuition described in editorial, best described in this img:
![](https://leetcode.com/problems/count-subarrays-with-fixed-bounds/Figures/2444/4.png)


# Approach
We have to keep 3 indices saved to determine count of valid subarrays ending at index i: 
1. most recent index where number is out of bounds
2. most recent index where maxK occurred
3. most recent index where minK occurred

Then at i: we can compute current array start - smallest index from where array has the most recent minK or maxK. 
If the recentOut index is smaller, then this means that from minOf(recentMinK, recentMaxK) to i, we have a valid array.

And this array is valid even if we add all items up to the left bound, or most recent index out of bounds. This is displayed in the prev image.

When we set recentOut to -1, we will even cover the case when whole array from start to i is valid, because we'll add that 1 (currentArrStart -(-1)).

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
$$O(n)$$

- Space complexity:
$$O(1)$$

# Code
```
class Solution {
    fun countSubarrays(nums: IntArray, minK: Int, maxK: Int): Long {
        var recentMin = -1
        var recentMax = -1
        var recentOut = -1
        var ans = 0L

        for (i in nums.indices) {
            if (nums[i] < minK || nums[i] > maxK) {
                recentOut = i
            }

            if (nums[i] == minK) {
                recentMin = i
            }

            if (nums[i] == maxK) {
                recentMax = i
            }
            val currentArrStart = minOf(recentMin, recentMax)
            ans += maxOf(0, currentArrStart - recentOut)
        }

        return ans
    }
}
```

# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
**Sliding window/two pointer method.**
![Screenshot 2023-03-04 191026.png](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/dee888c2-6ca7-40b2-af1e-7694133f9836_1677937238.686007.png)


# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
- as per constraint as soon as we find minK and maxK in our subarray, update counter to 1.
- now how we will keep track of this, with help of our vars **minI, maxI and end_of_ssI.**
- these vars indicates indexes of found **minK, maxK** element and as well as when we encounter element less than or greater than provided we include it's index too.
- **max(0, min(minI, maxI) - end_of_ssI)**: this ensures if till we have not found minK or maxK then update counter by 0, else update counter by 1.
- when any of **minI** or **maxI** is **-1** this will always **result in 0.**
- when we find both minK and maxK then **min(minI, maxI)** we take **because** it's **close to end_of_ssI** and will result in 1.
- next time when minI and maxI gets updated counter will get updated to 1.
- **return counter**. 

# Complexity
- Time complexity: O(N)
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity: O(1)
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def countSubarrays(self, nums: List[int], minK: int, maxK: int) -> int:
        minI = -1
        maxI = -1
        end_of_ssI = -1
        counter = 0
        for i in range(len(nums)):
            if minK <= nums[i] <= maxK:
                minI = i if nums[i] == minK else minI
                maxI = i if nums[i] == maxK else maxI
                counter += max(0, min(minI, maxI) - end_of_ssI)
            else:
                minI = -1
                maxI = -1
                end_of_ssI = i
        return counter
```

```
class Solution:
```

```
            if num == maxK:

            if minFound and maxFound:
```

solutions.content:
**Solution**:
Since a subarray must contains numbers between minK and maxK, any number outside such range will act as a divider and we can consider subarrays to the left and to the right of it independently.

Iterate through all numbers and find the count of valid subarrays ending at each number.
     
For a subarray starting from the divider and ending at some arbitrary number, we can shrink such subarray from the left and it will remain valid until it no longer includes minK or maxK. Thus, the count of valid subarrays is equal to the count of numbers starting from divider to the first of the last occurence of minK and maxK.
    
**Complexity**:
    Time: O(n)
    Space: O(1)

```
class Solution:
    def countSubarrays(self, nums: list[int], minK: int, maxK: int) -> int:

        # Initialize three variables to keep track of indices of latest divider, minK, maxK
        div, minLast, maxLast = 0, -1, -1

        # Initialize the result
        res = 0

        # Iterate through all numbers
        for i, num in enumerate(nums):

            # If the current number is a divider, we can disregard all numbers before it
            if not (minK <= num <= maxK):
                div, minLast, maxLast = i + 1, -1, -1
                continue

            # Update the latest indices of minK and maxK
            minLast, maxLast = (
                i if num == minK else minLast,
                i if num == maxK else maxLast,
            )

            # Update the result with the number of valid subarrays ending at the current number if we have seen minK and maxK
            res += (
                min(maxLast, minLast) - div + 1
                if minLast != -1 and maxLast != -1
                else 0
            )

        return res
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
Looking at a few base cases
1, 5 [1,5] = 1
1, 5 [2,1,5] = 2
1, 5 [1,5,1] = 3
1, 5 [2,1,5,1] = 5
you may notice that the count for a single pair of min and max is equal to `amount on left` * `amount on right`.
For multiple pairs, the number of substrings is the sum of single scores whenever we flip from minK to maxK, with updated bounds.


# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

Ex: 
`minK = 1  `
`maxK = 5  `
`nums = [2,1,5,1] `
`Expected Answer = 5`

Start:
Left bound = 0
Right bound = 3
count = 0

First step:
- First min/max value found: minK{1} @ i=1
- Other value: maxK{5} @ i=2
- Amount on left = (index of our first value - left bound + 1) = 2
- Amount on right = (right bound - index of our first flip + 1) = 2
- count += 2*2 // Count = 4
- Update our left bound: Left Bound = 2 //Our first index + 1

Second step:
- First min/max value found: maxK{5} @ i=2
- Other value: minK{1} @ i=3
- Amount on left = (index of our first value - left bound + 1) = 1
- Amount on right = (right bound - index of our first flip + 1) = 1
- count += 1*1 // Count = 5
- Update our left bound: Left Bound = 2 //Our first index + 1

Third step:
- First min/max value found: minK{1} @ i=3
- Other value: NOT FOUND. We're done with this string
- Return count // 5, as expected!

##### Now we repeat the above for each range of valid ints in nums and return the sum!

# Complexity
- Time complexity: $$O(n)$$
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity: $$O(1)$$
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def countSubarrays(self, nums: List[int], minK: int, maxK: int) -> int:
        returnable = 0

        ### Handle special case where min and max are same
        if minK == maxK:
            started = False
            l = 0
            for i, n in enumerate(nums):
                if n == minK:
                    if not started:
                        started = True
                        l = i
                else:
                    if started:
                        started = False
                        c = i-l
                        returnable += (c * (c+1)) // 2
            if started: # Finish it
                started = False
                c = i-l+1
                returnable += (c * (c+1)) // 2
            return returnable

        started = False
        l = r = -1

        ### Function to evaluate a single valid substring.
        ### - Must not contain invalid ints
        ### - Must contain minK and maxK 
        def evaluate_substring(l, r):
            returnable = 0

            ### Get our first value, minK or maxK and its index
            for i in range(l, r+1):
                n = nums[i]
                if n == minK or n == maxK:
                    curr_val = n
                    curr_val_idx = i
                    break

            ### Whenever we min or max and it's not equal to our current max, add score and flip our current value
            for i in range(curr_val_idx, r+1):
                n = nums[i]
                if n == minK or n == maxK:
                    if n != curr_val:
                        returnable += (curr_val_idx - l + 1) * (r - i + 1)
                        l = curr_val_idx + 1
                        curr_val_idx = i
                        curr_val = n
                    else: # n is current val
                        curr_val_idx = i

            return returnable

        # Split substrings at invalid characters and add idx if we've seen minK and maxK
        for i, n in enumerate(nums):
            if started:
                if minK <= n <= maxK:
                    r = i
                    min_found |= (n==minK)
                    max_found |= (n==maxK)
                else: # End of a run
                    started = False
                    if min_found and max_found:
                        returnable += evaluate_substring(l, r)
            else:
                if minK <= n <= maxK:
                    started = True
                    min_found = n == minK
                    max_found = n == maxK
                    l = i
        if started: # Finish last run
            if min_found and max_found:
                returnable += evaluate_substring(l, r)

        return returnable


                
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
The problem requires us to find the number of subarrays in an array where the minimum element is at least minK and the maximum element is at most maxK.
To solve the problem, I used a sliding window approach.
# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
I initialized three variables, lowest, highest, and inbetween, to -1. The lowest variable kept track of the last index where the minimum value was seen, the highest variable tracked the last index where the maximum value was seen, and the inbetween variable tracked the last index where a value outside the range of minK to maxK was seen.

Then, I iterated through the array and updated these variables based on the current element's value. If the current element was outside the range of minK to maxK, I updated the inbetween variable. If the current element was equal to minK, I updated the lowest variable, and if it was equal to maxK, I updated the highest variable.

Finally, for each index, I calculated the number of subarrays that end at that index and have a minimum value of at least minK and a maximum value of at most maxK. I did so by taking the minimum of lowest and highest and subtracting inbetween from it. If the result was greater than or equal to zero, I added it to the out variable, which represented the total number of subarrays that meet the criteria.
# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
Time Complexity of this solution is O(n), where n is the length of the input array nums. This is because the algorithm iterates through the array once and performs a constant number of operations at each index.
- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
Space complexity of this solution is O(1), as it only uses a constant amount of extra space to store the three variables lowest, highest, and inbetween. The space used by the input array nums is not considered extra space as it is required by the problem statement. Therefore, the solution has a space complexity that is constant with respect to the size of the input array.
# Code
```
class Solution:
    def countSubarrays(self, nums: List[int], minK: int, maxK: int) -> int:
        out, lowest, highest, inbetween = 0, -1, -1, -1
        for idx, num in enumerate(nums):
            if num < minK or num > maxK:
                inbetween = idx
            if num == minK:
                lowest = idx
            if num == maxK:
                highest = idx
            out += max(0, min(lowest, highest) - inbetween)
        return out
```

```
class Solution:
    def countSubarrays(self, nums: List[int], minK: int, maxK: int) -> int:
        n = len(nums)
        breaker = i = j = 0
        answer = maxKCount = minKCount = 0
        
        while i < n:
            while breaker < n and minK <= nums[breaker] <= maxK:
                breaker += 1
            
            while (minKCount == 0 or maxKCount == 0) and j < breaker:
                minKCount += int(nums[j] == minK)
                maxKCount += int(nums[j] == maxK)
                j += 1
            
            if j == breaker and (minKCount == 0 or maxKCount == 0):
                breaker += 1
                i = j = breaker
                maxKCount = minKCount = 0 
            else:
                answer += breaker - j + 1
                minKCount -= int(nums[i] == minK)
                maxKCount -= int(nums[i] == maxK)
                i += 1
        
        return answer
```

solutions.content:
```
class Solution:
    # Travel from left to right and if you find minK assing p1 to it and when you find maxK assing p2 to it
    # When you find p1 and p2 both with valid numbers in between all the numbers left of p1 which are valid
    # will be added to the answer. As you keep travelling right keep adding all the valid numbers from the left of p1
    # as those all will contribute to the answer! Hence wew need a variable to store leftmost id of valid number.
    def countSubarrays(self, nums: List[int], minK: int, maxK: int) -> int:
        res = 0
        p1 = p2 = left = -1
        for right in range(len(nums)):
            if nums[right] == minK: p1 = right
            if nums[right] == maxK: p2 = right
            if nums[right] < minK or nums[right] > maxK: left = right
            res += max(0, (min(p1, p2) - left))
        return res
```
solutions.code:
```
class Solution:
    # Travel from left to right and if you find minK assing p1 to it and when you find maxK assing p2 to it
    # When you find p1 and p2 both with valid numbers in between all the numbers left of p1 which are valid
    # will be added to the answer. As you keep travelling right keep adding all the valid numbers from the left of p1
    # as those all will contribute to the answer! Hence wew need a variable to store leftmost id of valid number.
    def countSubarrays(self, nums: List[int], minK: int, maxK: int) -> int:
        res = 0
        p1 = p2 = left = -1
        for right in range(len(nums)):
            if nums[right] == minK: p1 = right
            if nums[right] == maxK: p2 = right
            if nums[right] < minK or nums[right] > maxK: left = right
            res += max(0, (min(p1, p2) - left))
        return res
```

```
class Solution:
    def countSubarrays(self, nums: List[int], minK: int, maxK: int) -> int:
        ans = 0 
        ii = imin = imax = -1
        for i, x in enumerate(nums): 
            if minK <= x <= maxK: 
                if minK == x: imin = i
                if maxK == x: imax = i 
                ans += max(0, min(imax, imin) - ii)
            else: ii = i
        return ans 
```

solutions.content:
# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
Loop over each number, keep record of previous minK index, maxK index and outlier index.

When encounter a number in valid range [minK, maxK], calculate the num of valid subarrays that end with this number.

If previous outlier is before previous minK and previous maxK, the valid start of the subarray can be any index between [prev_out, min(prev_minK, prev_maxK)].

# Complexity
- Time complexity: One pass O(n)
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->


- Space complexity: O(1)
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def countSubarrays(self, nums: List[int], minK: int, maxK: int) -> int:
        n = len(nums) 
        # store indices of previous minK, maxK, outliers      
        prev_min, prev_max, prev_out = -1, -1, -1

        cnt = 0        
        for i in range(n):
            if nums[i] < minK or nums[i] > maxK: 
                prev_out = i
                continue               
            if nums[i] == minK: prev_min = i
            if nums[i] == maxK: prev_max = i
        
            # count subarrays, minK <= nums[i] <= maxK           
            if prev_out < prev_max and prev_out < prev_min:
                cnt += min(prev_max, prev_min) - prev_out
                            
        return cnt

```

solutions.content:
**Implementation**

**Step 1** We create an array `arr` to store the indices (`i`) whose corresponding values (`num`) are out of bound (i.e. `num < minK or num > maxK`) - these are the indices that cannot be included in any of the fixed-bound subarrays. In addition, we add `-1` and `len(nums)` as two gatekeepers on both sides. For example, if `nums = [1,3,5,2,7,5], minK = 1, maxK = 5` then `arr = [-1, 4, 6]`.

**Step 2** For each of the two neighboring indices `l` and `r` in `arr`, we count how many fixed-bound subarrays are within `nums[l + 1 : r]` by using a helper function.

To do this, we use a Counter `dic` to record the frequencies of the elements in the current subarray. Each time, we move the starting index (`i`) to the right by 1, and move the ending index `j` to the right as soon as both minK and maxK are included in the subarray (this can be easily checked since `dic` itself is a hashmap).

If this is the case, we count how many fixed-bound subarrays and added to the output of the helper function;

Otherwise, there is no fixed-bound subarrays that start with the current starting index which also implies that we don’t need to check further starting indices. We repeat this process by iterating all possible starting indices.
 
 **Solution**
```
class Solution:
    def countSubarrays(self, nums: List[int], minK: int, maxK: int) -> int:
        if minK > maxK: return 0
        
        def count(l, r):
            if l + 1 == r: return 0
            dic = Counter([nums[l]])
            ans, j = 0, l + 1
            for i in range(l + 1, r):
                dic[nums[i - 1]] -= 1
                while not dic[minK] * dic[maxK] and j < r:
                    dic[nums[j]] += 1
                    j += 1
                if dic[minK] * dic[maxK]: ans += r - j + 1
                else: break
            return ans
        
        arr = [-1] + [i for i, num in enumerate(nums) if num < minK or num > maxK] + [len(nums)]
        return sum(count(arr[i - 1], arr[i]) for i in range(1, len(arr)))
```

Initialize a variable ans to 0 and two pointers maxI and minI to -1.

Traverse the given array nums from left to right.

If the current element is not in the range of minK and maxK, reset the pointers to -1 and set the start pointer to i+1.

If the current element is equal to minK, update minI to i.

If the current element is equal to maxK, update maxI to i.

For each element, add the maximum of 0 and the minimum of minI and maxI minus start plus 1 to ans.

Return ans.

Damn. I spent quite long on this problem, coming up with convoluted divide and conquer solutions that kept giving wrong answers because I was double counting stuff all the time.
In the end, I just simplified my thinking process, eliminated the unnecessary information I was keeping track of, and came up with a really simple solution that holds in just a few line of codes. The intuition behind it is also really pretty simple to explain. It just took me really long to come up with it
Usually, the feeling when you finally get it is very satisfying, but here it was more like "All this for THAT?"

 `    def countSubarrays(self, nums: List[int], minK: int, maxK: int) -> int:
        
        count=0
        start=lastmin=lastmax=-1
        for i,num in enumerate(nums):
            if num==minK: lastmin=i
            if num==maxK: lastmax=i
            if num>maxK or num<minK: start=lastmin=lastmax=i
            count+=min(lastmin,lastmax)-start

        return count`

if I find solution bruce force, it for me. TLE

```python
def countSubarrays(self, nums: List[int], minK: int, maxK: int) -> int:
    n = len(nums)
```
